Comment: Can you give us a source for your homeless density claim? I don't believe it. As compared with Portland, Seattle, San Francisco? Population density is different in different cities. I would expect homelessness density to vary with population density, other things being equal, such as number unemployed or underemployed, prevailing wages, supply of apartments, etc.. 

I guess you could compare Eugene with a city of similar size. I'm constantly reading on Google News about other cities in which homelessness is a big problem -- especially for the homeless -- and a political issue, because it's the public face of poverty that a lot of people don't want to see.

Also the one night homeless counts, that local governments do all over the US, are notoriously inaccurate, because camping bans make it necessary to hide from the cops. Our best estimate is 2,000-3,000 at any one time.

In my experience, Eugene has always been a hard place to make a living.

Comment: Ya know, over in the Scandinavian countries like Denmark, they don't have 47%-ers.  Their 50% tax rate hits income over about $3,000/yr, and the top rate peaks out at about 60%.  Everyone pays into the system at pretty much the same rate.  Almost a flat tax.  The result: among the highest rates of credit card debt, consumption of anti-depressants, and alcoholism in the world.  The suicide rate has dropped from one the highest to close to our rate after the government started handing out anti-depressants like breath mints.

The biggest "loophole" we have in our tax system that costs the government the most revenue is the standard deduction and personal exemptions.  That's why we have a 47%.

The next two biggest, most costly loopholes are (a) tax free treatment of the employer-paid portion of group health insurance premiums, and (b) the mortgage interest deduction.

Still want to eliminate loopholes?  The people who benefit the most from loopholes are middle and lower class.

Comment: Your presumption is wrong.     Not every intersection is 4 way, or has a cross walk or a light.     So imagine turning right from a sidestreet onto eg:  Yonge Street,  making the turn, then a jaywalker steps out from between two parked cars just as you make the turn.       Or you see the pedestrian walking along the right sidewalk towards you (but at a safe distance for you to turn), then you look left, see an opening, look right, make the turn safely and discover that the pedestrian at that exact moment decided to dash from the sidewalk and cut across the main street right in front of where you just turned. Comment: What did a semen-stained blue dress from the Oval Office have to do with a land deal in Arkansas? After a couple of years of digging, that's all a partisan prosecutor could find against Bill Clinton. 
There's nothing unconstitutional about a prosecutor working an investigation finding evidence of other, related or even unrelated crimes. And of course, it's constitutional to pursue those other crimes. 
Watergate started as the investigation of a burglary and led to related crimes that brought Nixon down. 
Say a judge signs a search warrant based on evidence of an illegal poker game in Joe's basement. The cops come in and find they're not gambling, but there is an ounce of cocaine on the card table. Do they walk out and say: "Darn, too bad the warrant's for illegal gambling. Now we can't make a case for the cocaine."
Same as a prosecutor investigating MAFIA underlings to build a RICO case against the mob boss. She may use a drug case as a means of gaining cooperation.

Comment: What a ridiculous, hyperbolic, irresponsible article. Here's the real story on the ground in Vancouver, from the perspective of my fiancee and I who have been looking for a modest East side home for about two years:

Prices have not come down at the lower end of the market (read: entry level houses at $1.3-1.7 million), and there are very few good listings which would explain the drop in sales (not prices). Sometime around last summer, list prices caught up to the real sale prices, so the places that sell now are actually going for asking, or slightly below, however the sale prices still show a stable or even slight upward trend and the market is only "balanced" in the sense that now you might actually have a chance to make a slightly lower offer and/or have time to do a home inspection instead of just losing a bidding war. Prices are still about 40% higher than they were two years ago.

This is not the sound of a bubble burstin, but if it were, it would be good news to most people.

I don't think that's likely, and I think Paul Anthony owes the district an explanation of his actions.

Comment: Cars depreciate like a rock for the first 5 years - roughly. The first year's depreciation is massive, year-2 a little less massive, year-3 less than that and so on. The value only starts to level out after about five years when it holds a bit more steady, but maintenance starts to enter the picture. That is why leasing is such a bad deal. You continually ride the crest of the depreciation wave, paying for those very expensive early years. Leasing is far and away the most expensive way to drive a car.

Comment: Well not all those 216 million are covered by private plan as your state "1/6 to 1/7th have no coverage at all." The 1/6-1/7 are part of the 216 mil.

You state: "Pretending in the face of demonstrable evidence that our free market system is better than the system of universal coverage in every other developed country is deceptive."

But you conveniently forget that the US federal government already directly controls 67% of the nations healthcare right now, today. So there is nothing close to a free market system for healthcare. Pretending otherwise is deceptive.

If 1/6 have no coverage today that is 48-54 mil. of 325 mil. Americans without coverage. So 109 mil. citizens are covered by government healthcare, about 50 mil. do not have healthcare (as you stated) leaving about 166 mil. with private healthcare.

Income taxes on the 166 mil. already fund the largest percent of the 109 mil. and would have to fully cover an additional 50 mil. It is foolish to state the money is there now.

Comment: The problem with community papers is that they cover all the local and important (but not world-shattering) items that are actual of impact to your life: Municipal politics, local crime, local events.  These are all things that may directly impact your life.  They are also not as sexy as what gets reported in the "big media".  Famine in South Sudan is a big deal, but has little or no direct impact on your life here and there is little you can do about it.  With the internet, you would think the local news would flourish while the Google's of the world kill the big media.  Sadly, both local and national media is getting killed, local even faster as people refuse to read "paper".  I am as guilty as anyone else of "amusing myself to death" with international news of little direct impact.  How do we fix this?  We need those local reporters and media outlets.

Comment: From very young ages, my 4 kids had first hand visuals of the mortality and devastating trauma caused by guns on game animals. The cute bunny, deer, bear, etc. laying lifeless with a bloody hole in it. And it didn't get up to star in the next movie. Still, to the chagrin of my peers, I never let them point toy guns (or even their fingers) at a human and say "POW!" No squirt gun fights, playing 'Army', 'Cops and Robbers', 'Cowboys and Indians' or Grand Theft Auto type video games (These came out later and as "adults" they played them anyway...). And I screened (to the best of my ability) their intake of movies and TV. Perhaps I was viewed as a hard ass, but, I know first hand that it sucks to be shot. Yet, guns have always been an important tool in my life and I'm not one to throw out a hammer over a black thumbnail. I've kept them handy and I've kept them loaded. If you haven't taken the time to discipline your children before getting a gun, maybe you should get a baseball bat instead.

Comment: Boy, does this author ever have a bee in his bonnet about renewables. If he cared to check his facts, he would know that the increase in costs for electricity in Ontario are largely due to three factors: Nuclear plant refurbishment and maintenance costs, electrical grid rehabilitation (long overdue before it was started and absolutely necessary), and inflation. Only a small fraction of the increased costs is due to renewables. He is right in pointing out that the gas plants were overbuilt in Ontario and that has also added to increased costs. But the bottom line is, a renewables policy well implemented over time, as costs go down, is in fact the cheapest option for Ontario. Also, he is also misleadingly quoting peak period electricity costs, not average electricity costs, which are comparable to U.S. electricity costs.

Can a black baker refuse to make a birthday cake for a KKK grand dragon?  Can a black baker refuse to make a cake celebrating a KKK anniversary?  

Can a Jewish baker refuse service to a neo-Nazi?  Can a Jewish baker refuse to make a cake for a neo-Nazi protest rally?  

Can a liberal baker refuse to make a cake for a conservative politician?  Can a liberal baker refuse to make a cake for the Donald Trump inaugural celebration?

Comment: One can hardly call natural law theory or the use of reason to inform us about sin a "phobia" and it is the height of anti-intellectualism to do so.

But that aside in the written Gospels Christ is very clear about adultery being prohibited and since the very early days of the Church (as reflected in St. Paul's letters)  this has included all forms of unchastity, including homosexual acts.  

Naturally Christ didn't use the word "homosexuality" as the word and the concept (of an inclination toward this being somehow constitutive) are products of modern fads.

But even searching for prohibitions or excusing sin by reference to absence in the New Testament is wrong and un-Christian.  Christianity isn't Islam or Judaism founded on a book that lists naughty and nice things to do. We avoid these things--and remember that the ancients considered homosexual relations a universal temptation--and all sins because they are contrary to love of God and love of neighbor.

Comment: Reports by Fox News and the Daily Caller and Tattler giving oxygen to the Family Research Council and Traditional Values Coalition don't provide an accurate picture of what the curriculum actually says. Too often, curriculum outcomes are translated into scary scenarios like "the kids will be able to make up their gender" or "what they're trying to do is torpedo all gender" when, in fact, what the curriculum supports is teaching basic facts and definitions about phenomena that are well-documented scientifically. One of the articles also conflated the sex ed with the bathroom issue. Nice. 

No child is told that "you choose your gender just like you choose chocolate or vanilla". They are taught that gender is a spectrum and it's OK to be a boy or a girl and exhibit a variety of traits socially ascribed to either sex. I notice the K-group learn about good and bad touch, the Grade 3s talk about gender roles, and the Grade 4s learn gender is socially conditioned. Nothing to see here.

Comment: Grobarek, Without mineral extraction there is no economy to sustain Alaska. That is a fact. All mineral extraction activities have risk. So do most things in life.  The answer is to minimize the risk. I am confident that we can devise a financial mechanism that takes a percent of earnings on a continuing basis instead of a security bond and have funds to remediate after the mine exhausts. Nevertheless, if Mt. Redoubt, or one of the other activite volcanos in the Aleutian chain blows, it will make Pebble and afterthought with regard to harming salmon fisheries in Bristol Bay. And like earthquakes they will erupt sooner or later.  I do take issue with your characterization of Bristol Bay as huge sustainable economic engine with regard to salmon. In fact, Bristol Bay salmon account for about 10% of Alaska's fisheries value, and most of that goes to Outside operators. The environmental and emotional arguments about Bristol Bay salmon exceed the financial value of the fishery.

Comment: The numbers this month aren't particularly bad.  Job creation is keeping up with population growth (we need about 20,000 new jobs per month to keep up with population growth).  Job creation was in the private sector while the public sector actually saw some decline.  Job gains were clustered around Self-employed, which is a bit of a negative as self employed wages are, on average, much lower than employee wages.

Actually the biggest down-side to this report is more on the wage front.  Job growth was mainly in manufacturing which has wages toward the lower end of the spectrum (despite popular belief) while the biggest job losses where in Transportation and Warehousing (average paying field) and Educational Services (high paying field).

All in all average to decent, but not great.

Trudeau and government in general had little to nothing to do with this one way or the other.

Comment: The rail ridership projections in the alternatives analysis and the EIS were projected under the assumption that only the rail project is built and everything else says the same.  They did not take into account any other land use or transportation policies.  Rail is a tool that can be used to help increase transportation alternatives and reduce traffic congestion, but it is certainly not the only tool available to the City.  The City can increase rail ridership by changing zoning codes to allow for greater mixes of uses and lower parking requirements near the transit stations (TOD policies) as well as by building more bike lanes, better sidewalks and promoting other transportation alternatives such as carsharing and bikesharing.  All of these policy changes and transportation choice improvements are already underway in Honolulu.  The home run policy the City/State could institute would be congestion pricing during peak traffic hours on the H-1 freeway.

Comment: 1/2
For seven years, every time they repeated the mantra “Repeal and Replace”, Republicans were lying: they had no plan to replace the ACA. The farce they rejected last week was cobbled together in haste. Conservatives didn’t like it because it didn’t hurt enough people. Liberals didn’t like it because it would have hurt so many people -- upwards of 24 million people would have lost health insurance and health care.
During the campaign and transition and even in the early days of his presidency, Trump promised simultaneous repair/replace, seamless transition, universal coverage, lower costs and better health care. He was lying. 
Ryan promised that when the Republicans replace the ACA, no-one, not one American, will be worse off than under the ACA. He was lying.
I don’t know how many people voted for Trump because they believed his promises about health care, but those who did ought to insist that he propose a health care plan that reflects those promises.

Comment: The Snow River is above the Kenai Lake.  Just how many salmon spawn up there?  I don’t know, do you?  Just what are the impacts if that dam is built?  I don’t know, do you?

There will be impacts, that’s for sure.   But, what are they and are they worth the trade off for a power source that doesn’t emit CO2?  Like previously mentioned, fossil fuels emit CO2 which is acidifying the oceans.  What impact does that have on salmon long term?

If nothing else, proposals like this bring the opportunity to acquire a lot of data about a system that wasn’t available before. Seems like many folks here have the attitude that “all dams are bad - period.” 

At this point in time, you should focus your attention on making sure they collect the appropriate data to make an informed decision about what the real impacts might be versus a wholesale NO.

Comment: Since it is no one's sole province to define "civil rights" your statement may only be true according to your own definition.

e.g. does an unborn foetus have "civil rights"?  is the answer the same on the day of birth?

These thorny issues are and have been (hotly?) debated even in Supreme Courts globally.

Even "settled science" is inaccurate as scientific theories are often reversed and science retains the "right" to so so in perpetuity.  Can we guarantee that in the future a demographically different electorate may not overturn various existing laws?  Do future generations have the right to do so?

For me the issue becomes problematic when we adjudge the aforementioned votes as being about "civil rights".  Instead we should just say he voted for/against a specific issue.

Comment: Luke,
You correctly point out the general rule that investment is negatively correlated to interest rates, but fail to differentiate between fixed investment and short-term portfolio flows.

Whilst high interest rates discourage fixed investment, they encourage carry trade- short-term portfolio flows. South Africa has been relying on this carry trade for years now to plug the balance of payments deficits and to an extent the twin deficits.

I agree with your view that there is merit in expanding the mandate of the SARB in a manner that does not risk hyperinflation or debasement of the currency.

A builder cannot build a house just using a spirit level - he needs lots of other tools.
Similarly, you cannot manage an economy by using the tool of interest rates alone.

Comment: I am "dwelling on the treaty method" because you falsely claimed that a valid treaty existed. Having lost that argument, you're now trying to move the goalposts. The legality of using a joint resolution to annex Hawaii was hotly debated back in 1898 and remains unresolved. That is not to say, of course, that 100+ years later a US court would ever rule that annexation was NOT valid--it would undoubtedly decline to decide the issue under the Political Question Doctrine or some similar theory. As the US Supreme Court stated in an Indian Law case back in 1823, "Conquest gives a title which the Courts of the conqueror cannot deny." NAFTA is instructive; the legality of its adoption by joint resolution was challenged in Made in the USA Found. v. United States, 242 F3d. 1300 (11th Cir. 2001), cert. denied, 534 U.S. 1039 (2001), in which the court ducked the issue by holding that the method of adoption was a "political question" beyond the competence of the courts to decide.

Comment: The itineraries of presidential candidates in battleground states (and their allocation of other campaign resources in battleground states, including polling, organizing, and ad spending) reflect the political reality that every gubernatorial or senatorial candidate knows. When and where every voter is equal, a campaign must be run everywhere.

With National Popular Vote, when every voter is equal, everywhere, it makes sense for presidential candidates to try and elevate their votes where they are and aren't so well liked. But, under the state-by-state winner-take-all laws, it makes no sense for a Democrat to try and do that in Oregon or Wyoming, or for a Republican to try it in Wyoming or Oregon.

The main media at the moment, TV, costs much more per impression in big cities than in smaller towns and rural area. Candidates get more bang for the buck in smaller towns and rural areas.

Comment: Patricia Steen - The EC creates 51 statewide elections for President. It is a perfect example of how local politics works. It reflects the demographics of each state rather than the demographics of the nation as a whole, because the "nation" was never foreseen by our Founders. They thought like I do. I'm an Alaskan first and an American after that. When I vote, I vote for Alaskan interests. New Yorkers are permitted to vote for their own interests. And, truthfully, that is how we live ... until we get a president in office like Obama who thinks the whole country should walk off a cliff in lockstep with his commands ... which was exactly the reason the Founders created the EC, so that New York could not decide for Rhode Island who Rhode Islanders would vote for.

Because when you do away with the EC, the election is decided by the big cities (always for Democrats) and the rural and exurban areas have zero voice in the government from now on. That used to be called slavery, by the way.

Comment: Reading this article gives me hope. My son has just turned 13 and we have been dealing with JIA of psoriatic subtype for two years now. Mostly inflammation in his large toe and ankles. Garrett also plays football. His dad is actually the coach for his school team. He was limited during the season due to ankle flare ups. Comment: Having observers on scene collecting data helps insure the viability of fisheries. Having current and historical data on fisheries is a win all the way around. Ive been long lining on boats where there aren't enough bunks to go around when an observer is on and we'll "hot bunk" it. No one has complained because they  knew that the data observers collect is important. Ive been set netting and have had to take observers out to pick the gear with us, it was no biggie at all. Most observers bend over backwards to stay out of the way and not hinder a fisher trying to make a living. Its actually nice to have someone different around to chat with and hear some different stories. From what I've seen, people who care about the future of fishing aren't bothered by taking observers on small vessel. Oh and the state doesn't pay for the observers fyi.

Comment: The issue is that the future career path is less obvious than many other disciplines.  As others have noted English, History, Philosophy and others are often precursors to future degrees notably Law.  A good portion of the humanities, social sciences and even the sciences were never intended to be direct outlets to careers.  Some disciplines just have seeming more obvious paths or mesh well with identifiable job titles.  Although that too can be source of frustration - like assuming that everyone with an accounting degree files taxes for a living or that everyone with a law degree plans to be a trial lawyer.

It seems to be that if you feel your degree is being undervalued that perhaps you haven't done a very good job at articulating your educational background and career aspirations.  If you can't explain it to a friend or acquaintance how on earth to you plan to communicate those skills to a potential employer?

Comment: One question would be, what does it shift our dependence to?  Because if it's a shift toward wind & solar then it's likely to lead to a boondoggle.  Very few people seem to understand the fundamental problems with diffuse, intermittent energy sources.  In fact it's not even quite correct to call them 'sources,' e.g. PV solar in Germany, with similar insolation as western Washington, was shown recently to be a net energy sink, with an EROI of less than one (consuming more energy than it creates), similar to ethanol.  Let's not enact legislation that sends us down that road again.

At the very least we should be sure that the social cost of carbon isn't actually negative.  The planet is currently greening, at least in part due to higher CO2 levels, and that's likely to be a benefit.  The notion that we should pay now to avoid paying later is based generally on our current understanding of the climate, which is primitive, and specifically on climate models, which are even more primitive.

Comment: This article strains very hard  to create an equivalence where none ever existed. There was never any left-wing version of the "Moral Majority" just as there was never any left-wing version of "First Things" which sought to forge a coalition between liberal mainstream Protestants, liberal Catholics, and the Democratic party for the sake of gaining political power. Comment: When ballistic missiles are launched in the general direction of North America, it is nearly impossible to determine if their target will be Seattle, or Vancouver, Toronto or Detroit, and so on, since most targets in Canada are close to the US border.

And in general the ability of anyone to "hit a bullet with a bullet" has been disputed, but this is not like Iraq firing Scuds at Israel, if a country fires more than one missile it might still be hard to know what it is or what the intention is with enough time to react, and a country with as many missiles as Russia or China would be able to overwhelm and missile defense system.

Canada, as a member of Norad and Nato, is already in a relationship with the US that commits them to come to our defense. Who is going to fire one or two nuclear missiles at Canada, and why?

In short, our participation had little practical benefit for our defense, was unlikely to work, and sent the wrong message to the world.

Comment: And Alaska also has municipal sales taxes up to 7.5% muck up, in the muskeg. Oh, and the Federal Income Tax is legal there.

Sellers in the city are required to “add the applicable tax … to the total selling price and collect the applicable tax from the buyer at the time of the sale…. All sales tax collected or which should have been collected pursuant to this chapter are city monies for which both the seller and the buyer are at all times liable to the city.”

In addition to finding in favor of the City of Bingham, the Supreme Court found the taxpayer’s argument to be frivolous: “his unlawful conduct in failing to comply with the certification requirements did not eliminate his duty to collect tax.” See Supreme Court No. 1-15706 for more details.

Comment: I used to work in Tok in 1990-92, and often drove past the HAARP site in Gakona. During the winter, you could see the tracks in the snow from vehicles entering and departing the facility. There was a light at the gate, so it was clearly visible from the Tok Cutoff highway. At the time, Nick Begich and others ranted on about how it was a grand conspiracy. However, you could see that there was only a twin set of tracks in the deep snow, going in and out. I presume they were those of a night watchman, or something similar. It was supposed to be a massive plot, yet there was only that single set of tracks per 24 hours period.  The driver must have been a VERY busy guy.

Comment: I was bitten by a neighbor's dog when I was 10.  The dog was introduced to me as friendly, and I petted it with no problems with the neighbor around.  The next day I went over to pet it because I am a big animal lover.  The dog attacked me, going for my throat.  I blocked with my arm, and it was severely torn up.  I was scared it wouldn't let me go, but the owner saw what was happening and called it off me.  I ran home and my parents took me to the emergency room.  The bite was so bad that they couldn't stitch it together.  The wound had to heal on its own and once fully healed, I would need plastic surgery.  The dog was also not vaccinated, and I had to have rabies shots.  Those were extremely long needles that were placed on alternating days in my abdomen.  They were excruciating.  The neighbor and his dog were so well liked in the neighborhood that everyone turned against my family, who up until then was always invited to all neighborhood activities.

Family dogs do bite people.

Comment: What is not clear from this article is whether the hunts took place in the park or in the preserve portions of Wrangell-St, Elias National Park and Preserve.  The article states:  "The lodge was permitted to provide sport hunting guide services within the park."  This is incorrect.  Sport hunting is allowed by law within the preserve portion of the unit - provided it is conducted in compliance with state and federal laws - including those laws pertaining to guided hunts.  It is not allowed in the park portion of the unit.  If the hunts occurred in the park or if they were conducted using illegal practices, then those involved should be prosecuted in full accordance with both state and federal law. In the future ADN writers need to be more careful about how they report these type of incidents.

Comment: Random musings:
-Peer reviewed economic studies (one from BC in particular) have shown that increases in minimum wage are met with reductions in working hours. Employers will work their existing staff harder to compensate.
-If you are an adult supporting a family and you make minimum wage; it's not society's fault or the 1%, it's yours. What did you do with the first 25 years of your life?
-This gives employers a stronger motivation to use technology to replace people. It's already happening; the fast food cashier will not exist in 2-3 years. Regular cashiers will not exist in 5 years. There are dozens of other jobs that are in their last decade of existence.
-You can't legislate your way to prosperity
-Paying higher wages for low skilled work sends the wrong signals and destroys incentives. You are not supposed to live comfortably in low skilled jobs. Otherwise, why would anyone try to do better?

Comment: A party of five tourists from Nome, accompanied by an old-timer chef, travel by snowmachines to Fairbanks. During the first day goings-on, the tourist are rude and obnoxious. That evening, the chef includes a handful of moose nuggets to the stew. He asks the tourists, "How's the stew?" Their answer, "Tastes like moose shit!" Just then the chef pulls out a revolver and says, "The next complaint will be met with lead." Along the trail the following day, no rude behavior and all is quiet. That night the chef adds more nuggets to the stew. No complaints. Third night, the chef adds more nuggets. Still, no complaints. Fourth night, just outside Fairbanks, the chef asks, "How's the stew?" The tourists reply, "Tastes like moose shit...but good!"

Comment: "Were you thinking the rich should pay no more than their share of income?"

Not at all,  I'm simply pointing out that the ratio get more out of whack as you go up in income.  For example:
-The avg taxpayer in the $200-$500k bracket makes 6.4 times a much as the avg in the  $40-50k bracket but pays 20 times a much in income tax.
-The avg taxpayer in the $500-$1 Million bracket makes 11 times a much as the avg in the  $50-75k bracket but pays 34 times a much in income tax.

One thing that exacerbates that is that, as income goes up, deductions and exemptions are a lower percentage of AGI.  As income does down, a higher percentage is excluded!

Comment: Fans have no desire for "brakes", nor should they, they are fans after all. Just a few months ago, fans were proclaiming  (some still are) "journeyman", "backup at best", "average ceiling - maybe", "Trevor Orton" and many more less complimentary names and insults. Through all that, a few of us were defending TS, saying "it's too early for those labels" and very few were saying "pump the brakes" then.

So, now that there's more data and the bandwagon is getting dangerously top heavy, nobody really cares (or wants) a safe ride with brakes pumped at every turn, especially when you'er 2-0 on the first 2 turns. Fans want the thrill of being 1st to cross the finish line, with every heart stopping moment and every breath taking spectacle that makes them cling to their seats and squeal for more along the way. That's football, that's entertainment and that's what fans love.

So damn the brakes, full speed ahead! GO BRONCOS!

Comment: The entire premise of this piece is flawed. The economy broadly speaking is not booming — the metrics usually show only that the money owned by rich people is making money in financial markets. Indeed, Canada's GDP numbers are ginned up by the gains of the banks in offshore financial markets. The official unemployment rate is something between a joke and a fig leaf for governments who use such numbers to shame and blame the unemployed with the — mostly — unspoken insinuation that if you can't find work at a living wage, it must be your fault. Late stage capitalism begins to look more and more looks like a game of musical chairs where those with means and secure employment get to bid on the increasingly scarce chairs while their fellow citizens are condemned to precarious and contingent existence.

Comment: Poloz was asked by Marcel Boyer after his speech where the 2% target came from and his response contained a lot of errors. He said it started in 1994 or 1996 or thereabouts and that 2% was already being used elsewhere as an inflation goal. It was introduced in February 1991, when the Bank of Canada first became an inflation-targeting central bank as a target for the end of 1995, to be replaced by something lower thereafter. The 1993 renewal agreement ruled that it would continue to be the target after 1995, and it has never been changed since. The Bank of Canada was the very first inflation-targeting central bank to adopt a target rate as opposed to a target range, so the 2% target rate started here.

Comment: The appropriate mix for almost all investors is a combination of riskier (stocks) and lower risk (bonds and other fixed income) holdings.

Holding only equity positions is unnecessarily volatile and provides little or no opportunity to take advantage of market corrections. Equity only is suitable only for young people who (1) have very little money invested now and (2) are making regular contributions such as a monthly PAC.


Holding fixed income only is suitable only when the spending goal is near term.

In all other situations a balanced portfolio of some proportion will produce the best combination of safety and growth.  Even in a low yield environment like today, fixed income represents dry powder if nothing else.

The other critical requirement is to have the conviction and discipline to rebalance your portfolio when others are too fearful.

Comment: There are two issues at play here: commercial interests, versus moral concern about food animals' well-being. 

Farmers that house animals are using the same arguments that building owners used before the advent of fire suppression systems for human safety- 'It's too costly,' chief among those complaints. Both in the past and today, they point to the fact that private dwellings aren't required to have fire suppression systems. So why would we require them in apartment buildings, office towers or... barns?

It's clear that requiring fire suppression systems in apartments, etc didn't destroy the housing and construction industries. The reason why is that these systems are but a tiny fraction of the overall construction cost, and that cost is fully recovered over the life of the building. In a poultry barn's lifetime it might house millions of chickens, so the installation cost per bird is just pennies. It's not like it's going to send your grocery bill through the roof.

Comment: If the NHL, as it should, went with a different scoring system, so that wins in reg were worth 3 pts, it would go a long way to eliminating the possibility of a team making/missing the playoffs because of its record in extra time.

Beating another team in reg should be worth more than beating that team in 3-on-3 OT, or worse, the SO.

Fla is presently 2 pts behind Bos for the 8th playoff spot, with a game in hand.  TB sits 1 pt behind Bos, also with a game in hand.  Bos has 13 wins in reg, TB 14--Fla has all of 7.  Not even close.  However, if the NHL awarded 3 pt for a win in reg and kept 2 pts for a win in extras, then Bos 50 pts, TB 49, Fla 42.

It matters.  

Soccer does not use SO to decide games in reg, that's only for playoffs and tournaments where a winner has to be decided for the series to continue.

Comment: Joseppi, I'm always outraged by dictators. So I wouldn't classify my concern as sudden, and the interest here relates to a local legislator making a recent visit with one. As I've written before, I use the acronym TOPICAL to determine if something is newsworthy (the more news factors involved, the more newsy): T (Timely; yes, recently happened); O (Odd or unusual; can you recall the last time a wayward junior U.S. legislator met unannounced with a heinous dictator?); P (Proximity, AKA the local tie; check); I (Impacts a large number of people; I'd say a U.S. rep delving into international affairs and then taking the dictator's line of rhetoric back to her country qualifies); C (Conflict or controversy involved; check); A (About a prominent person in the community; check); L (Larger issue involved; yes, as you have noted, intervention/or not is one of the biggest issues in U.S. foreign policy; intervention should be a last resort, but it seems to me that Syria qualifies at this point).

Comment: If your account is factual, I suspect a family of ermine moved into your neighborhood at more or less the same time.  I have witnessed mass-migration of rats away from a site shortly after ermine moved in.  This was in Kodiak, and I've heard of the same thing from others whose opinion I trust.

Mustelids (weasels, etc.) are much better mousers/ratters than cats.  One species was domesticated for this purpose long before cats were.  I've seen mink eliminate rodents from a Sitka property to where their rodent traps stayed empty for years.

It's also only fair to say I believe NO anecdotes from cat-nutters, because "anecdote" is to them a euphemism for lying through their teeth.  So forgive me if your "screen name" causes me to regard your claim with skepticism.

Ermine scent drives away commensal rodents.  Cat scent attracts them if they're infected with toxoplasmosis.  This facilitates the pathogens' return to feline digestive tracts, which is the only place they can reproduce.

Comment: Real,

It's good to remember that around 2004-5 several of our Chartered Banks lobbied to be allowed to merge and participate directly in the US high octane securitization market (CDO3 et al) but that the Department of Finance and Bank of Canada said no; they would not be allowed to consolidate of to participate in the securitization market except in the relatively 'boring' Canadian version.

There was much moaning in the Canadian financial industry that this doomed them to indefinitely remain a backwater.  However, by 2009 6 of the 10 largest North American Banks by capitalization were Canadian Chartered Banks because of the losses incurred by the leading US Banks.

In short, regulation by Federal Government and agencies in Canada were instrumental in saving our Chartered Banks, our domestic financial system and the Canadian Government and people loads of money and the preventing a deep domestic depression from occuring here.

Comment: From a selfish perspective, I don't have a problem at all with this change – except it sounds like my snow-skiing may have to  give way to water skiing!
 I lived in Juneau for a decade or so, and grew to love those wet, coolly comfortable summers – with the occasional brilliantly sun-shiny day being so welcome! 
 If Southcentral became more like that I would be happy to continue to not roast in the summer; and all the rain would be great for our spruce forests in combating the spruce bark beetle. 
I'd miss the snow skiing… But so much of that has been harder to find over the past several years with our warm and snowless winters, that maybe I'm getting used to it…
Will still be far better off than any other part of the USA, and we can still be thankful that we have made and continued to make this place our home.

Comment: Seven year old Mohamed arrived at his classroom on the first day of school.
“What’s your name?”, asked the teacher.
“Mohammad,” he replied.
“You’re in Ireland now,” replied the teacher, “So from now on you will be known as Mike.”
Mohammad returned home after school.

Comment: Pure democracy is a form of government in which people vote on all policy initiatives directly. 

Guaranteeing the election of the presidential candidate with the most popular votes and the majority of Electoral College votes (as the National Popular Vote bill would) would not make us a pure democracy. 

Equal representation of the states in the U.S. Senate is explicitly established in the U.S. Constitution. This feature cannot be changed by state law or an interstate compact. 

In contrast, the U.S. Constitution explicitly assigns the power of selecting the manner of appointing presidential electors to the states. The enactment by a state legislature of the National Popular Vote bill is an exercise of a legislature’s existing powers under the U.S. Constitution. 

Adding up votes of all voters and winning with the most popular votes is the method that is used in virtually every other election in the country.

Comment: Don,
Your statement that only "4 of 13" ESA stocks in the Columbia River are located in the Snake River Basin ignores a very important point: the Snake River drainage is massive. This is the largest area of spawning habitat for salmon and steelhead on the Columbia River and also historically produced more biomass than any of the other Columbia River tributaries.  There is a huge amount of viable habitat in the Snake River drainage that isn't being fully utilized.  Furthermore, other ESA listed salmon and steelhead in the Columbia system utilize the Snake before backtracking and moving into their drainages.  Most of the "record returns" of salmon are hatchery produced fish and not wild fish that spawned in their native rivers; the increased rate of return is largely attributed to better ocean conditions and less with the dam operations.  We've reached a point of diminishing returns on dam operations...each improvement will be more costly with less benefit.

Comment: The Legislature fiddles while the state burns.

A shutdown would not only cost the state millions of dollars in economic and investment damage, but even laying off every state worker would end up costing the state millions of dollars. Because state workers are laid-off, not furloughed like federal employees in shutdown, the state is legally required to cash-out the employee leave banks of every single employee effected. You can safely assume hundreds of thousands of hours of leave would have to be written off the books with checks, and long-service employees who have climbed the payscale will get large payouts (a quarter million or more for some folks I know who have several thousand hours in the bank).

The brinksmanship is a bad joke. It doesn't get anything accomplished other than making our state government look as dysfunctional as the federal government. The Legislature needs to do its damned job.

Comment: Interesting article with interesting theories on the causes.  But I would like to add another part of the story that holds merit. 

In an economy that is service based ( Tourism/Hospitality ) we have a need for service employees.  But the problem is..., they have no place to live.  Where can a server/dishwasher afford to live around here?  

So there you have it.  Increase the number of tourists, build a bunch of nice buildings with million dollar condos and cute cafes on the ground floor without adequately providing a mechanism/means  for "employee housing".  A lot of people have been screaming about this for a long time now, and it is simple math.  This is not a surprise in my opinion. 

It is not just a cultural resistance to work these jobs or competition amongst employers.  It is about HOUSING costs and the livability of the community.  That is likely the base cause and effect relationship here.

Comment: To think.  I've owned my home for nearly 40 years now, and still have a high mortgage.  I'm not alone as a local homeowner on fixed income. For example, fire sprinklers for us, closer fire hydrants,  home emergency fire alarm systems. In social fairness, the City Council must consider subsidies to private homeowners for comparable needs when considering subsidizing private condo owners.  We all pay the same taxes.  Paraphrasing Mufi's quote, "the life of one homeowner is worth it."  I'm no different than the private condo owner, except I have the heavier individual burden of maintaining a home and yard.  But, my hand is out ready for the subsidies.

Comment: I'm pretty positive that the NLRA section 8 deals with coverage.  It's the major reason why UAW couldn't sign up the 700+ people who wanted a union because there were 800+ people who didn't want one. If the numbers had been reversed, then there would have been 700~ people who belonged to a union they didn't want to belong to!  If it were as simple as monopoly contracts, then why must they hold an election?  Toss the monopoly clause, and viola!  No need for an election!  People sign up to be represented, and that is that.

If you want labor out of politics, then go after Citizen's United.  One look at the lobbyists hanging out at your state capital will show that labor is barely represented at all.  You'll be lucky to find 2 lobbyists representing the working class compared the the dozens upon dozens who shill for big business.

Comment: Nothing like starting an editorial out with a completely false premise. Our staff is gathering public input on a national consultants recommendations for efficiency improvements to our waste management system. It is NOT "the commissioners plan". I do appreciate Mr. Mangnall's review of the multifaceted benefits of a well run solid waste management system and I will say that I will be looking for a solution to the economic problems the system faces that balances the risks of impacting all the benefits the system provides including preventing the trashing of our public lands.

Comment: In light of available information, I conclude the following:

(1) A Burmese python that size hunts on the ground.  In terms of energy-exchange, there's little percentage in a 100-lb snake climbing, and balancing itself for long periods, in a tree when arboreal prey is generally smaller than that it can find on the ground.
(2) Pythons specialize in proportionately LARGE prey, enabling them to feed infrequently.  They're ambush predators.  I've seen a ball python fast for over a year.
(3) Most snakes--including pythons--usually seek out burrows rather than superstructure.  I once crawled beneath a friend's house to remove his 10 ft. reticulate python that had become lodged in his plumbing.
(4) Being albino suggests basking in the sun wasn't an option.
(5) In a region utterly lacking native snakes, probability of a second snake leaving a sloughed skin approaches zero.
(6) The snake did travel some--at least as far as the neighbor's trailer and back.  Probably not much further.

Comment: The hallucinatory effects of larium are so well known it has effectively been banned for SCUBA diving for a couple of decades - hallucinate underwater and you are likely to die.

There are safer anti-malarial drugs but they need to be taken daily. So far as I can see, the fact that larium needs only be taken once a week was the deciding factor in the US, UK and Canadian governments' decisions to issue it. Daily pills might be a nuisance; for a soldier; but lifelong mental problems is a far bigger problem,

Comment: I wish we could see more of this work--shots from the exhibit aren't available online either. I like the way Georges incorporates the traditions of icon painting into his work. The pose he has chosen for the mother of God is the "Theotokos of the sign," which dates back to the first century. Mary is depicted from the waist up with Christ in the centre of her upper body surrounded by a a bright light. He doesn't actually lean on her--it's more of a hovering. Traditional for the Christ child to be depicted with a scroll representing the new life, the new law . . . an interesting detail to be dropped, almost suggesting the hellishness just around the corner.

That consists on state lands of helicopters and fixed wing who to pursue and kill bears and wolves while airborne, taking bear over bait, all the game board trademark horrors practiced on state lands is now possible on our national wildlife refuges. As example 652 wolves have been slaughtered in the Upper Tanana Preadtor Control area since 2005, 40 or so within the past few weeks. The refuge rule that was removed by Murkowski, Sullivan and Young as resolution sponsors exempts rural subsistence but Walker doesn't bother with that detail as he pleads the rule would take food away from rural reaches. Comment: The rangers are on the mountain for the climbing season for the purposes of managing the resource and enforcing trash and human waste regulations in this fragile environment. And if necessary, they perform rescue operations. The mandatory climber briefings and interaction with the public has demonstratively decreased accidents and increased climber safety. Just like with the roads, facilities, trails, maintenance, road patrol, interpreters, backcountry rangers, etc. that exist in other national parks, it's the cost of doing business, so to speak, of having Denali National Park as a treasured public resource. Get over it.
The cost of rescues for climbers, nationwide, pales in comparison to the cost of rescuing drunk boaters, lost children, and many other people doing things I'm sure you don't consider 'frivolous'. Also, forcing people to pay all costs of rescues can, and will, result in people delaying calling for help until the situation is much worse, and more risky to resolve.

Comment: I reply to my own post ---

Each action has consequences. The consequence of a legal abortion is the fetus. That such is 'murder', or that the fetus is a person, is contentious. Some consider it a sin. Some do not.

Illegal, back-alley, back-woods, second-story walk-up-clinic abortions have in the past, and will have in the future, consequences to indisputable living persons -- the women at risk in unsanitary conditions, the spouse if made a widower, the other children if rendered motherless, society in general if non-supervised teens roam streets. 

The potentially greater number of living persons affected as the result of illegal, unsanitary abortions is why I consider actions leading to such is the greater sin, and should be considered so even by those who believe abortion to be sinful.

Comment: Standing under the elevated rail platform outside Yankee Stadium the other night, the intense noise created by trains above reminded me of why the O’ahu rail tracks are inside a concrete “bowl.” The parapet walls deflect some of the (lateral) noise upward; it helps at track level but those in buildings above that level may not be pleased with their proximity to rail. As (I am sure) Mr. Callan knows, adding ramps for buses on the elevated guideway also places rail collections to date at risk. He probably also knows that urban magnetic levitation is the quietest and most environmentally friendly rail system. A maglev-only guideway for the remaining ten miles to Ala Moana Center would not require concrete “shielding” for noise and would be much less physically and visually imposing. It also will save hundreds of millions of dollars in construction costs, and billions later for operations and maintenance.

Building codes have different rules for high-rise and single family residences because of the number of people would can be in the building at the same time.

Comment: Wrong. Lots of doctors will change jobs. They can get salary positions or go to the US or overseas. A 10-20% drop in a business could mean laying off a medical clerk. Comment: Ancient scientists knew the world was round. The ancient Greeks even managed to measure its diameter with a reasonable degree of accuracy with triangulation.   The art of astrological navigation only makes sense with a round world. 

Many other anachronistic opinions were not "peer reviewed" "consensus". Geocentrism was dogma and right out of the Bible. The scientists knew that the ridiculously elaborate models needed to explain astrological movements were nonsense and that putting the sun at the centre made way more sense, but they knew that if they said otherwise the Church would (possibly literally) have their head on a platter.  It wasn't until evidence became overwhelming that the church acquiesced and admitted error. 

Peer review works great when you use empirical, evidence, and most of the modern world is a product of this process. Attacks on it are usually politically motivated and driven by dislike of the findings that arise for whatever reason.

Comment: You mean "what the media TELL you". I have more than a clue, I have excellent journalism to show me. Media is a plural word. A medium is a means of transmitting information. The town crier was a news medium, as were the Troubadors of the Middle Ages. Theater and opera are media. We have print media, spoken media such as radio, visual media such as TV and film. We have electronic media such as this forum and the internet. Comment: The writer fails to note what, for me, was the most important take-away of Wente's piece, namely: "The real goal – far more important – should be to teach kids enough math and science to understand the world in which they operate."

The world is awash with people who have willfully abandoned the ability to look at data and evidence, to think critically, to question intelligently and to understand how science and technology connects to their everyday world. If we don't want a next generation of climate denying, anti-vaxxing, fake-news reading, celebrity-opinion-obsessed folks etc then we need to re-instill the ability to think critically and question intelligently. Science education is imperative not just for the "doing" of science, but for the appreciation by EVERYONE of science, and the formalism of critical thinking it is based on.

Learning coding is fine, but it is truly understanding broader scientific PRINCIPLES and applying them to everyday life that makes one a better citizen.

Comment: As I watched 9 more pre-orders roll in today, I had to think, darn, that's 9 more traction non-indicators for Steve.

Your opinion that pre-orders aren't a viable traction indicator is, frankly, nonsense. We clearly articulate preorders as "strong leads" in our offering circular. They are-- anyone who's put cash down, refundable or not, is a much stronger lead than someone who merely signs up for a test drive. Yes, we still have to build a compelling product, and continue to communicate that product to our pre-order customers. While some will certainly fall off, to me it seems likely they will more than be made up for from folks who are unwilling to place a preorder on something that is not yet in production, which is a very common refrain we hear.

Anyway, thanks for the positive home-town encouragement. Means a lot!

Comment: I fly multiple times a year, and I've been through ORD and DFW, and dozens of other airports.  ORD is hardly the model of efficiency, or simplicity.  There's a reason they have a problem expanding and why there was even talk of replacing in not many years back.

DIA was built with the future in mind, with room to expand.  Yes, it relies heavily on the train rather than simply walking.  By relying on the train, distance between concourses and the terminal becomes mostly irrelevant (the train gets you there in just a few minutes).  Thus they were able to spread concourses out more, allowing room for expansion and making it safer and better for the airplanes to maneuver on the tarmac.  

If you're walking the skybridge, then you're choosing the long walk instead of the train which is the primary method provided. We often do the same, but purely because of the security lines are usually better there.  Every airport struggled with security designs post-9/11. Hopefully this helps that.

They choose to follow or not follow guidance. Even if there is a lack of guidance, the virtues of right and wrong are virtually universal at a very young age. 

You can't be held accountable for someone elses actions unless you were knowingly involved in the events of the crime.

Comment: The lead ministry is Municipal Affairs & Housing. The requirements of Ontario's Provincial Policy Statement (PPS) are not optional: Section 3 of the Planning Act requires that planning decisions "shall be consistent with" policy statements issued under the Act. In other words, decisions made by municipalities and other decision-making bodies must comply with PPS requirements.

The Policy section of the PPS is extensive, clear and internally consistent. Section 3.0 specifically addresses the need to protect public health and safety and provides the following prescriptive statement: 
"Development shall be directed away from areas of natural or human-made hazards where there is an unacceptable risk to public health or safety or of property damage, and not create new or aggravate existing hazards" (p. 30).

The only questions would be:
- are transmission pipelines human-made hazards?
- do they present an unacceptable risk to public safety?
- do they present an unacceptable risk re.

Comment: Losing a kidney isn't the problem.  Renal cancer, once it moves outside the kidney, is quite resistant to chemo.  Not referenced in the article, and not mentioned in her statement, is the fact that because the cancer has already moved beyond the kidney, she is medically Stage 4, M1.  The presence of a cancer lesion in a rib is not good.  Bone is a prime growing medium for cancer tumors.   The best outcome for Renal cancer patients comes when the cancer is localized to the kidney, and the kidney is removed.  Once Renal cancer cells have spread beyond the kidney, treatment outcomes are very poor.  The 5 year survival rate for Stage 4 is only 8%.  My cousin was diagnosed at State 3, had his kidney removed, but only lived 2 years after that.  Once the cancer was found elsewhere, it spread very quickly, and treatments were of very limited effectiveness.  I don't see how she runs for re-election.

Comment: They opposed conventional oil corporations because most of them are mandated by law, to maximize profits for the share-holders ... which results in the rape and ruin, profits at all costs management style.

ASRC/NSB does not operate on a maximize profits structure. They allow management leeway, and a portion of what would have ordinarily been profits, paid out to share-holders, to go towards insuring that the environment has sufficient and real protections.

Several states have enacted laws which allow for "Benefit Corporations" which can have bylaws that protect the management from getting sued by the share-holders, if they don't absolutely maximize profits at all cost.

Alaska might do well to legislate benefit corporations. It would go far to counter the traditional dig/drill and destroy. Make it mandatory for any extractive operations, to have a specified set of bylaws, that encourage ecologically sound practices.

Benefit Corporations don't absolutey have to be non-profits either.

Comment: Alice, thank you for believing in the possibility of a great newspaper for Alaska. When we were younger, well before the pipeline hardened our reality, we used to say that "Alaska is a State of Mind". Our future seemed limitless; our politics was aspirational. The Chronicle of our path toward that aspirational horizon was the Anchorage Daily News. The ADN was progressive not out of adherence to any political agenda, but out of loyalty to its roots buried in the good soil of our young State & it's progressive Constitution. Kay Fanning et al started the ADN inspired by and mindful of the exigencies of a new state. From Kay Fanning to Alice Rogoff our faithful lamp was lit and I thank you. I wish the best for both you and our newspaper.

Comment: This is a fascinating topic & one that needs a considerable amount of discussion.  While the US economy has always been "capitalism", it has also been one in which workers trade their labor for wages, which they then use to purchase the goods produced. While "capital" has always been important, the fortunate few who have held meaningful amounts of it have always required labor to produce goods.  For several decades the supply of total US capital has steadily been consolidated into fewer & fewer hands. With the advancement of robotics & AI, automation is likely to steadily eat away at the number of available jobs - to the point where eventually there may not be enough of them to go around.  What does the US economy look like if only capital (and almost no labor) is required to produce goods? One can debate the speed & scale of automation, but eventually we'll need to find solutions that transcend conventional debates between fiscal conservatives and social liberals.

Comment: Anchorage has been honored to have Mike Dunham reporting  on the arts in our state's largest newspaper for the last 50 years.  It's a challenge for artists in any medium to gain exposure and receive constructive criticism from knowledgeable observers.  Mike has covered the arts widely and fairly.  We were thrilled when he accepted our invitation to speak on publicizing art and artists at a meeting of the Alaska Watercolor Society, and I was personally gratified not long afterwards when he covered my own first show.   We've learned a lot from his columns, and cannot help but agree with his observation that "The [Anchorage] museum's highest use, I believe, is supplying a venue for Alaska artists to have their work seen by other Alaskans."  How sorely we will miss Mike's insight and commentary on our arts scene.  
Robert Winfree, Past President
Alaska Watercolor Society

Comment: No one knows how to gauge te outcome based on the ranked ballot.  But isn't the challenge greater than that?   
Each EDA counts as 100 points and the first candidate to get 16901 points, or more, is the winner.  This means that EDA's with a small number of members carry a lot of weight.  If one candidate has 28% support concentrated in many EDA's with few members, that candidate ha a much better chance than another candidate with 35% support concentrated in a few ridings in the GTA.
This is the same approach the Liberals used to choose Justin Trudeau.  Apparently, he had broad support getting over 80% of the points on the first round.  This time around, it seems like a real crap shoot.

If one buys that interpretation, then much falls into place. The other Gospel passage on divorce does not describe the dispute, the two options presented to Jesus, but simplifies that divorce is proscribed "except for adultery," which just so happen to be the choice Jesus made in the parallel passage. In other words, an apparent discrepancy disappears--Jesus accept divorce on the principles of Leviticus (adultery), and reject divorce as a male prerogative that can be exercised for any reason.

Finally, after all of that, I would invite them to read Amoris Laetitiae, and understand it as the Church still struggling after 2000 years to deal with divorce. 

The purpose of the internal forum is not to defend the magisterium over against individual conscience, as you suggest.

Comment: "...the idea took hold that it was beset by a clutch of institutional and electoral problems known as the "democratic deficit." In reality, the democratic deficit was little more than opposition code for Liberal hegemony, so fixing the democratic deficit meant limiting or hindering the power of the federal government."

Uh, no Andrew. The "democratic deficit" was the result of a continuing slide in voting participation. And the term did not simply refer to federal politics, it was heard throughout many provinces. BC, Ontario, PEI, New Brunswick and Quebec all formed a task force or commission to explore electoral reform with 3 of the 5 triggering referendums. 

It's one thing to write a polemic, it is another to manufacture facts. And you might have heard some complaints about our electoral system in the last election and the deliberate failure of the special committee. If you listen hard enough or read beyond the headlines, you will realize the democratic deficit is alive and well.

Comment: I see several posts saying that Toronto should raise residential property taxes.     It's completely misleading to say that a Toronto homeowner pays "less" taxes than eg:  the 905.       What people are comparing is property tax rates, not the total tax bill.     The rates are per a phased in market value assessment.     Therefore, Toronto homeowners have seen a disproportionate rise in their property taxes as a result of the appreciation of their homes.     This means their total tax bill is proportionately higher for a physically similar property.     Eg:  a 1 million dollar house in Mississauga might be worth 5 times that if it were dumped into the middle of Toronto.

Using my own home as an example, I pay (rounding down) about $12K/year in property taxes (I'm including our separate garbage collection fee).    For that, I get old services.   Eg:   I had to replace the old clay sewer line this year at a cost of $10K (City Maple's tree roots encroached and broke the line).

Comment: Mr. Calder:  I agree.  The entire corn-based ethanol industry is one big scam.  It is not effective as a subtituteadditive for gasoline.  It is very expensive to produce.  As you say, it depletes the soil and depends entirely on petrochemical fertilizers.  And it takes millions of acres of farmland out of food production and has a huge detrimental impact of the commodities market.  The use of more and more pesticides is just a little "bonus."  We live in the country and a neighbor keeps 24 hives on our land.  He tells stories of beekeepers being completely wiped out as their hives were killed by such pesticides.  We're capable of being such damn fools.  Gary Crum
